name: Site of Hayes Place (Pitt the Younger's birthplace)
description: Birthplace of William Pitt the Younger in 1759 within his father's country estate.
address: Hayes Place Estate (now residential streets, Hayes, Bromley, Greater London)
fun_fact: Although the house was demolished in 1933, nearby Chatham Avenue preserves the 'Pitt' name from the original estate :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}.

name: Holwood House grounds
description: Site of Pitt’s holiday retreat where he consulted with abolitionist Wilberforce under the famous Wilberforce Oak.
address: Holwood Park Drive, Keston, Bromley, Greater London
fun_fact: A conversation in 1788 under the oak prompted Wilberforce to pursue abolition in Parliament :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}.

name: Blue plaque at 120 Baker Street
description: Townhouse where Pitt lived from 1803 to 1804 during his second term as Prime Minister.
fun_fact: The English Heritage plaque notes he was the youngest PM ever, aged just 24 :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}.

name: Statue of William Pitt the Younger, Hanover Square
description: Bronze statue erected in 1831 to honour Pitt, located at the south end of Hanover Square Garden.
fun_fact: Reform Bill agitators tried to pull it down on its unveiling day, but it survived intact :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}.

name: Monument to Pitt the Younger, Westminster Abbey
description: Memorial above the west entrance honouring Pitt’s service to the nation.
address: Westminster Abbey, Dean’s Yard, Westminster SW1P 3PA
fun_fact: The memorial, by Richard Westmacott, was funded by Parliament after his death in 1806 :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}.

name: Burial vault of the Pitts, Westminster Abbey north transept
description: Final resting place of Pitt the Elder (d.1778) and his son, Pitt the Younger (d.1806).
address: North Transept, Westminster Abbey, Westminster SW1P 3PA
fun_fact: Their vault bears their initials on a small stone, despite grand monuments nearby :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}.

name: Guildhall monument to Pitt the Younger
description: Commemorative plaque/statue in London’s medieval Guildhall celebrating Pitt’s parliamentary legacy.
address: Guildhall, Gresham Street, City of London EC2V 7HH
fun_fact: This 19th‑century memorial marks Pitt’s reforms in public administration :contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}.

name: Lansdowne House (tenant site)
description: Townhouse where Pitt resided temporarily during his premiership in the 1780–1800 period.
address: 9 Fitzmaurice Place (off Berkeley Square), Mayfair, London W1K
fun_fact: Originally built for Prime Ministers Bute and Shelburne, it later hosted Pitt the Younger :contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}.

name: Berkeley Square Plane Trees
description: Gardens planted in 1789—during Pitt’s time—that would have shaded promenades he frequented.
fun_fact: The oldest London plane trees here were planted in the exact year of the French Revolution :contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}.

name: Site of Argyll House wedding
description: Location where Pitt the Elder married Hester Grenville in 1754, linking the Pitt family to Georgian society.
address: Argyll Street (site of former Argyll House), Soho, Westminster
fun_fact: Argyll House later belonged to future PM Lord Aberdeen—London stays can be full-circle! :contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}.
